poem:
A Sudden Ban  

In the garden of games,  
a fence rises, barring passage—  
whispers of Palestine  
flutter through stadium aisles,  
a testament to voices,  
unheard yet felt.  
The field, a distant sea;  
the cheer, a phantom wave.  
For in the silence of fans,  
the quietude speaks louder  
than any roaring crowd.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "No 10 says talks happening ‘at pace’ across government to lift ban on Maccabi Tel Aviv fans attending Aston Villa match – live 1.09pm BST Sundus Abdi is a Guardian reporter. Groups including Youth Front for Palestine, Game Over Israel, and Football Against Apartheid have praised the ban on Maccabi Tel Aviv fans attending the Europa League match as a “victory for Palestine”, crediting “popular pressure” and “direct action” by activists in Birmingham and across". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
